{IERC20-balanceOf}."},"burn(uint256)":{"details":"Destroys `amount` tokens from the caller.     * See {ERC20-_burn}."},"burnFrom(address,uint256)":{"details":"See For example, if `decimals` equals `2`, a balance of `505` tokens should be displayed to a user as `5,05` (`505 / 10 ** 2`).     * Tokens usually opt for a value of 18, imitating the relationship between Ether and Wei.     * NOTE: This information is only used for _display_ purposes: it in no way affects any of the arithmetic of the contract, including {IERC20-balanceOf} and {IERC20-transfer}."},"decreaseAllowance(address,uint256)":{"details":"Atomically decreases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.     * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described in {IERC20-approve}.     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.     * Requirements:     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address. - `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least `subtractedValue`."},"increaseAllowance(address,uint256)":{"details":"Atomically increases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.     * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described in {IERC20-approve}.     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.     * Requirements:     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address."},"mint(address,uint256)":{"details":"See {ERC20-_mint}.     * Requirements:     * - the caller must have the {MinterRole}."},"name()":{"details":"Returns the name of the token."},"symbol()":{"details":"Returns the symbol of the token, usually a shorter version of the name."},"totalSupply()":{"details":"See {IERC20-totalSupply}."},"transfer(address,uint256)":{"details":"See {IERC20-transfer}.     * Requirements:     * - `recipient` cannot be the zero address. - the caller must have a balance of at least `amount`."},"transferFrom(address,address,uint256)":{"details":"See {IERC20-transferFrom}.     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is not required by the EIP. See the note at the beginning of {ERC20};     * Requirements: - `sender` and `recipient` cannot be the zero address. - `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`. - the caller must have allowance for `sender`'s tokens of at least `amount`."}}},"userdoc":{"methods":{},"notice":"This contract is for the Swarm BZZ token. This contract inherits         from all the above imported contracts indirectly through the         implemented contracts. ERC20Capped is Mintable, Burnable is an ERC20"}},"settings":{"compilationTarget":{"project:/contracts/Token.sol":"Token"},"evmVersion":"byzantium","libraries":{},"optimizer":{"enabled":false,"runs":200},"remappings":[]},"sources":{"project:/contracts/Token.sol":{"keccak256":"0xccefb0d611dbf2a6de7dc210d0344d60782858c79f8ec9e14c76665ff674a630","urls":["bzzr://71cab159bdca7a5bb6e63fb2a062466eca0aff847ccf6f5ee90c2f25d75f7745"]}},"version":1}

nodes.documentation:
@notice  Below is all the required smart contracts from the OpenZeppelin
         library needed for the Token contract. This is the inheritance
         tree of the token:
 *          Token
         |--ERC20Detailed
         |  |--IERC20
         |--ERC20Capped
         |  |--ERC20Mintable
         |     |--MinterRoll
         |     |  |--Context
         |     |  |--Roles
         |     |--ERC20
         |        |--IERC20
         |        |--Context
         |        |--SafeMath
         |--ERC20Burnable
         |  |--Context
         |  |--ERC20
         |     |--IERC20
         |     |--Context
         |     |--SafeMath
nodes.name: Context

nodes.documentation:
@dev Interface of the ERC20 standard as defined in the EIP. Does not include
the optional functions; to access them see {ERC20Detailed}.
nodes.name: IERC20

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the amount of tokens in existence.
nodes.name: totalSupply

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the amount of tokens owned by `account`.
nodes.name: balanceOf
transfer

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the remaining number of tokens that `spender` will be
allowed to spend on behalf of `owner` through {transferFrom}. This is
zero by default.
     * This value changes when {approve} or {transferFrom} are called.
nodes.name: allowance

nodes.documentation:
@dev Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the caller's tokens.
     * Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
     * IMPORTANT: Beware that changing an allowance with this method brings the risk
that someone may use both the old and the new allowance by unfortunate
transaction ordering. One possible solution to mitigate this race
condition is to first reduce the spender's allowance to 0 and set the
desired value afterwards:
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/20#issuecomment-263524729
     * Emits an {Approval} event.
nodes.name: approve

nodes.documentation:
@dev Moves `amount` tokens from `sender` to `recipient` using the
allowance mechanism. `amount` is then deducted from the caller's
allowance.
     * Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
     * Emits a {Transfer} event.
nodes.name: transferFrom
Transfer

nodes.documentation:
@dev Emitted when the allowance of a `spender` for an `owner` is set by
a call to {approve}. `value` is the new allowance.
nodes.name: Approval

nodes.documentation:
@dev Wrappers over Solidity's arithmetic operations with added overflow
checks.
 * Arithmetic operations in Solidity wrap on overflow. This can easily result
in bugs, because programmers usually assume that an overflow raises an
error, which is the standard behavior in high level programming languages.
`SafeMath` restores this intuition by reverting the transaction when an
operation overflows.
 * Using this library instead of the unchecked operations eliminates an entire
class of bugs, so it's recommended to use it always.
nodes.name: SafeMath

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the addition of two unsigned integers, reverting on
overflow.
     * Counterpart to Solidity's `+` operator.
     * Requirements:
- Addition cannot overflow.
nodes.name: add

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the subtraction of two unsigned integers, reverting on
overflow (when the result is negative).
     * Counterpart to Solidity's `-` operator.
     * Requirements:
- Subtraction cannot overflow.
nodes.name: sub

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the subtraction of two unsigned integers, reverting with custom message on
overflow (when the result is negative).
     * Counterpart to Solidity's `-` operator.
     * Requirements:
- Subtraction cannot overflow.
     * _Available since v2.4.0._
nodes.name: sub

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the multiplication of two unsigned integers, reverting on
overflow.
     * Counterpart to Solidity's `*` operator.
     * Requirements:
- Multiplication cannot overflow.
nodes.name: mul

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the integer division of two unsigned integers. Reverts on
division by zero. The result is rounded towards zero.
     * Counterpart to Solidity's `/` operator. Note: this function uses a
`revert` opcode (which leaves remaining gas untouched) while Solidity
uses an invalid opcode to revert (consuming all remaining gas).
     * Requirements:
- The divisor cannot be zero.
nodes.name: div

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the integer division of two unsigned integers. Reverts with custom message on
division by zero. The result is rounded towards zero.
     * Counterpart to Solidity's `/` operator. Note: this function uses a
`revert` opcode (which leaves remaining gas untouched) while Solidity
uses an invalid opcode to revert (consuming all remaining gas).
     * Requirements:
- The divisor cannot be zero.
     * _Available since v2.4.0._
nodes.name: div

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the remainder of dividing two unsigned integers. (unsigned integer modulo),
Reverts when dividing by zero.
     * Counterpart to Solidity's `%` operator. This function uses a `revert`
opcode (which leaves remaining gas untouched) while Solidity uses an
invalid opcode to revert (consuming all remaining gas).
     * Requirements:
- The divisor cannot be zero.
nodes.name: mod

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the remainder of dividing two unsigned integers. (unsigned integer modulo),
Reverts with custom message when dividing by zero.
     * Counterpart to Solidity's `%` operator. This function uses a `revert`
opcode (which leaves remaining gas untouched) while Solidity uses an
invalid opcode to revert (consuming all remaining gas).
     * Requirements:
- The divisor cannot be zero.
     * _Available since v2.4.0._
nodes.name: mod

nodes.documentation:
@dev Implementation of the {IERC20} interface.
 * This implementation is agnostic to the way tokens are created. This means
that a supply mechanism has to be added in a derived contract using {_mint}.
For a generic mechanism see {ERC20Mintable}.
 * TIP: For a detailed writeup see our guide
https://forum.zeppelin.solutions/t/how-to-implement-erc20-supply-mechanisms/226[How
to implement supply mechanisms].
 * We have followed general OpenZeppelin guidelines: functions revert instead
of returning `false` on failure. This behavior is nonetheless conventional
and does not conflict with the expectations of ERC20 applications.
 * Additionally, an {Approval} event is emitted on calls to {transferFrom}.
This allows applications to reconstruct the allowance for all accounts just
by listening to said events. Other implementations of the EIP may not emit
these events, as it isn't required by the specification.
 * Finally, the non-standard {decreaseAllowance} and {increaseAllowance}
functions have been added to mitigate the well-known issues around setting
allowances. See {IERC20-approve}.
nodes.name: ERC20

nodes.documentation: @dev See {IERC20-totalSupply}.
nodes.name: totalSupply

nodes.documentation: @dev See {IERC20-balanceOf}.
nodes.name: balanceOf

nodes.documentation:
@dev See {IERC20-transfer}.
     * Requirements:
     * - `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- the caller must have a balance of at least `amount`.
nodes.name: transfer

nodes.documentation: @dev See {IERC20-allowance}.
nodes.name: allowance
approve

nodes.documentation:
@dev See {IERC20-transferFrom}.
     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is not
required by the EIP. See the note at the beginning of {ERC20};
     * Requirements:
- `sender` and `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`.
- the caller must have allowance for `sender`'s tokens of at least
`amount`.
nodes.name: transferFrom

nodes.documentation:
@dev Atomically increases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.
     * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for
problems described in {IERC20-approve}.
     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.
     * Requirements:
     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
nodes.name: increaseAllowance

nodes.documentation:
@dev Atomically decreases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.
     * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for
problems described in {IERC20-approve}.
     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.
     * Requirements:
     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
- `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least
`subtractedValue`.
nodes.name: decreaseAllowance

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: transfer from the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: transfer from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: transfer from the zero address"

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: transfer to the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: transfer to the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: transfer to the zero address"

nodes.documentation:
@dev Moves tokens `amount` from `sender` to `recipient`.
     * This is internal function is equivalent to {transfer}, and can be used to
e.g. implement automatic token fees, slashing mechanisms, etc.
     * Emits a {Transfer} event.
     * Requirements:
     * - `sender` cannot be the zero address.
- `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`.
nodes.name: _transfer

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: mint to the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: mint to the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: mint to the zero address"

nodes.documentation:
@dev Creates `amount` tokens and assigns them to `account`, increasing
the total supply.
     * Emits a {Transfer} event with `from` set to the zero address.
     * Requirements
     * - `to` cannot be the zero address.
nodes.name: _mint

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: burn from the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: burn from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: burn from the zero address"

nodes.documentation:
@dev Destroys `amount` tokens from `account`, reducing the
total supply.
     * Emits a {Transfer} event with `to` set to the zero address.
     * Requirements
     * - `account` cannot be the zero address.
- `account` must have at least `amount` tokens.
nodes.name: _burn

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve from the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: approve from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve from the zero address"

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve to the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: approve to the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve to the zero address"

nodes.documentation:
@dev Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the `owner`s tokens.
     * This is internal function is equivalent to `approve`, and can be used to
e.g. set automatic allowances for certain subsystems, etc.
     * Emits an {Approval} event.
     * Requirements:
     * - `owner` cannot be the zero address.
- `spender` cannot be the zero address.
nodes.name: _approve
_burnFrom

nodes.documentation:
@title Roles
@dev Library for managing addresses assigned to a Role.
nodes.name: Roles

typeDescriptions.typeString: function (struct Roles.Role storage pointer,address) view returns (bool)

@return bool
nodes.name: has

nodes.name: ERC20Mintable
mint
ERC20Burnable

nodes.documentation:
@dev Destroys `amount` tokens from the caller.
     * See {ERC20-_burn}.
nodes.name: burn

nodes.documentation: @dev See {ERC20-_burnFrom}.
nodes.name: burnFrom

nodes.documentation: @dev Extension of {ERC20Mintable} that adds a cap to the supply of tokens.
nodes.name: ERC20Capped

nodes.documentation:
@dev Sets the value of the `cap`. This value is immutable, it can only be
set once during construction.
@dev Returns the cap on the token's total supply.
nodes.name: cap
_mint

nodes.documentation: @dev Optional functions from the ERC20 standard.
nodes.name: ERC20Detailed

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the name of the token.
nodes.name: name

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the symbol of the token, usually a shorter version of the
name.
nodes.name: symbol

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the number of decimals used to get its user representation.
For example, if `decimals` equals `2`, a balance of `505` tokens should
be displayed to a user as `5,05` (`505 / 10 ** 2`).
     * Tokens usually opt for a value of 18, imitating the relationship between
Ether and Wei.
     * NOTE: This information is only used for _display_ purposes: it in
no way affects any of the arithmetic of the contract, including
{IERC20-balanceOf} and {IERC20-transfer}.
nodes.name: decimals
Token

nodes.documentation: @dev    Initialises all the inherited smart contracts

         |     |  |--Roles

         |        |--IERC20
         |        |--Context
         |        |--SafeMath
         |--ERC20Burnable
         |  |--Context
         |  |--ERC20
         |     |--IERC20
         |     |--Context
         |     |--SafeMath

@dev See {IERC20-transfer}.
     * Requirements:
     * - `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- the caller must have a balance of at least `amount`.
attributes.name: transfer

attributes.documentation: @dev See {IERC20-allowance}.
attributes.name: allowance
approve

attributes.documentation:
@dev See {IERC20-transferFrom}.
     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is not
required by the EIP. See the note at the beginning of {ERC20};
     * Requirements:
- `sender` and `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`.
- the caller must have allowance for `sender`'s tokens of at least
`amount`.
attributes.name: transferFrom

attributes.documentation:
@dev Atomically increases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.
     * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for
problems described in {IERC20-approve}.
     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.
     * Requirements:
     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
attributes.name: increaseAllowance

attributes.documentation:
@dev Atomically decreases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.
     * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for
problems described in {IERC20-approve}.
     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.
     * Requirements:
     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
- `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least
`subtractedValue`.
attributes.name: decreaseAllowance

attributes.documentation:
@dev Moves tokens `amount` from `sender` to `recipient`.
     * This is internal function is equivalent to {transfer}, and can be used to
e.g. implement automatic token fees, slashing mechanisms, etc.
     * Emits a {Transfer} event.
     * Requirements:
     * - `sender` cannot be the zero address.
- `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`.
attributes.name: _transfer

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: transfer from the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "ERC20: transfer from the zero address"
attributes.value: ERC20: transfer from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: transfer to the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "ERC20: transfer to the zero address"
attributes.value: ERC20: transfer to the zero address

attributes.documentation:
@dev Creates `amount` tokens and assigns them to `account`, increasing
the total supply.
     * Emits a {Transfer} event with `from` set to the zero address.
     * Requirements
     * - `to` cannot be the zero address.
attributes.name: _mint

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: mint to the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "ERC20: mint to the zero address"
attributes.value: ERC20: mint to the zero address

attributes.documentation:
@dev Destroys `amount` tokens from `account`, reducing the
total supply.
     * Emits a {Transfer} event with `to` set to the zero address.
     * Requirements
     * - `account` cannot be the zero address.
- `account` must have at least `amount` tokens.
attributes.name: _burn

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: burn from the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "ERC20: burn from the zero address"
attributes.value: ERC20: burn from the zero address

attributes.documentation:
@dev Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the `owner`s tokens.
     * This is internal function is equivalent to `approve`, and can be used to
e.g. set automatic allowances for certain subsystems, etc.
     * Emits an {Approval} event.
     * Requirements:
     * - `owner` cannot be the zero address.
- `spender` cannot be the zero address.
attributes.name: _approve

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve from the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "ERC20: approve from the zero address"
attributes.value: ERC20: approve from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve to the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "ERC20: approve to the zero address"
attributes.value: ERC20: approve to the zero address

attributes.name: _burnFrom

attributes.name: ERC20Mintable
mint
ERC20Burnable

attributes.documentation:
@dev Destroys `amount` tokens from the caller.
     * See {ERC20-_burn}.
attributes.name: burn

attributes.documentation: @dev See {ERC20-_burnFrom}.
attributes.name: burnFrom

attributes.documentation: @dev Extension of {ERC20Mintable} that adds a cap to the supply of tokens.
attributes.name: ERC20Capped

attributes.documentation:
@dev Sets the value of the `cap`. This value is immutable, it can only be
set once during construction.
@dev Returns the cap on the token's total supply.
attributes.name: cap
_mint

attributes.documentation: @dev Optional functions from the ERC20 standard.
attributes.name: ERC20Detailed

attributes.documentation: @dev Returns the name of the token.
attributes.name: name

attributes.documentation:
@dev Returns the symbol of the token, usually a shorter version of the
name.
attributes.name: symbol

attributes.documentation:
@dev Returns the number of decimals used to get its user representation.
For example, if `decimals` equals `2`, a balance of `505` tokens should
be displayed to a user as `5,05` (`505 / 10 ** 2`).
     * Tokens usually opt for a value of 18, imitating the relationship between
Ether and Wei.
     * NOTE: This information is only used for _display_ purposes: it in
no way affects any of the arithmetic of the contract, including
{IERC20-balanceOf} and {IERC20-transfer}.
attributes.name: decimals
Token

attributes.documentation: @dev    Initialises all the inherited smart contracts

approve(address,uint256).details: See {IERC20-approve}.     * Requirements:     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.

burn(uint256).details: Destroys `amount` tokens from the caller.     * See {ERC20-_burn}.

cap().details: Returns the cap on the token's total supply.

constructor.details: Initialises all the inherited smart contracts

decimals().details: Returns the number of decimals used to get its user representation. For example, if `decimals` equals `2`, a balance of `505` tokens should be displayed to a user as `5,05` (`505 / 10 ** 2`).     * Tokens usually opt for a value of 18, imitating the relationship between Ether and Wei.     * NOTE: This information is only used for _display_ purposes: it in no way affects any of the arithmetic of the contract, including {IERC20-balanceOf} and {IERC20-transfer}.

decreaseAllowance(address,uint256).details: Atomically decreases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.     * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described in {IERC20-approve}.     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.     * Requirements:     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address. - `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least `subtractedValue`.

increaseAllowance(address,uint256).details: Atomically increases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.     * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described in {IERC20-approve}.     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.     * Requirements:     * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.

mint(address,uint256).details: See {ERC20-_mint}.     * Requirements:     * - the caller must have the {MinterRole}.

name().details: Returns the name of the token.

symbol().details: Returns the symbol of the token, usually a shorter version of the name.

transfer(address,uint256).details: See {IERC20-transfer}.     * Requirements:     * - `recipient` cannot be the zero address. - the caller must have a balance of at least `amount`.

transferFrom(address,address,uint256).details: See {IERC20-transferFrom}.     * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is not required by the EIP. See the note at the beginning of {ERC20};     * Requirements: - `sender` and `recipient` cannot be the zero address. - `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`. - the caller must have allowance for `sender`'s tokens of at least `amount`.

userdoc.notice: This contract is for the Swarm BZZ token. This contract inherits         from all the above imported contracts indirectly through the         implemented contracts. ERC20Capped is Mintable, Burnable is an ERC20
